questions.text: A newborn present with treatment-resistant congestive heart failure, a bulging anterior fontanelle, a bruit upon auscultation, and a transfontanellar ultrasound as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vein of Galen malformation

 

  • The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of a Vein of Galen malformation, which is a rare vascular anomaly.
  • It occurs when the embryonic precursor to the vein of Galen forms an arteriovenous malformation, leading to heart failure due to the high output demands placed on the heart by the arteriovenous shunt.
  • The bruit on auscultation over the fontanelle and the findings on ultrasound are characteristic of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalocele: Encephalocele is a defect in the neural tube causing brain tissue to protrude outside the skull. It does not typically cause congestive heart failure or a bruit.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: Medulloblastoma is a malignant pediatric brain tumor usually presenting later in infancy or childhood, not as heart failure or with a bruit in the newborn period.

 

Option C. Arachnoid cyst: An arachnoid cyst is a cerebrospinal fluid-filled sac and may present with hydrocephalus, but it does not cause congestive heart failure or a bruit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vein of Galen malformation should be considered in neonates with resistant congestive heart failure, bulging fontanelle, and bruit on auscultation, especially if imaging reveals a midline mass with ventricular dilation.
  • This vascular anomaly requires specific neurosurgical and medical intervention to manage the high-output cardiac failure and potential hydrocephalus.

choices.text: It’s a form of ID reaction
Koebnerization is never seen
Presence of Wickhams striae is classical for this condition
Mucous membrane is not involved

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with multiple pin pointed dome shaped skin lesions over hands as shown in the image below. What is true about the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucous membrane is not involved

 

  • The diagnosis for a patient who presented with multiple pin pointed dome shaped skin lesions over hands is Lichen nitidus.
  • Lichen nitidus typically presents with small, shiny, skin-colored papules on the skin, and while it shares some clinical features with lichen planus, mucous membranes are typically not involved in lichen nitidus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It’s a form of ID reaction: An ID reaction is a secondary skin eruption occurring in response to a primary infection or inflammation elsewhere in the body. Lichen nitidus is not classified as an id reaction.

 

Option B. Koebnerization is never seen: Koebnerization, or the Koebner phenomenon, can occur in lichen nitidus, where new lesions develop in areas of skin trauma.

 

Option C. Presence of Wickhams striae is classical for this condition: Wickham's striae are classically associated with lichen planus, not lichen nitidus, and are not a feature of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen nitidus is characterized by numerous small, shiny papules primarily on the skin, with the mucous membranes generally not involved.

choices.text: More than 10% of the TB patients tested for HIV in the district are known to be HIV positive.
More than 12% of the TB patients tested for HIV in the district are known to be HIV positive.
More than 15% of the TB patients tested for HIV in the district are known to be HIV positive.
More than 20% of the TB patients tested for HIV in the district are known to be HIV positive.

questions.text: In the context of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), how is a high priority TB-HIV district defined based on the criteria set for integrating TB and HIV control measures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More than 10% of the TB patients tested for HIV in the district are known to be HIV positive.

 

  • According to the guidelines from the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), a district is classified as high priority for TB-HIV intervention if over 10% of TB patients tested for HIV are found to be HIV positive. This threshold is set to identify and prioritize areas with significant overlap between TB and HIV infections, enabling targeted healthcare interventions to manage and reduce the incidence of both conditions effectively.

 

Educational Objective

 

Categorisation of Districts under NTEP (for HIV-TB Co-infection)

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents to the gynecology outpatient department with amenorrhea. On examination, she exhibits Tanner Stage V breast development but lacks pubic and axillary hair. Ultrasound reveals an absent uterus and non-developed gonads. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

 

  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's clinical presentation and ultrasound findings.
  • AIS is a condition where an individual who is genetically male (46,XY) is resistant to male hormones (androgens).
  • As a result, the person has the physical traits of a female but does not develop a uterus or ovaries.
  • The presence of Tanner Stage V breast development despite the absence of pubic and axillary hair is indicative of the body's inability to respond to androgens.
  • The absence of a uterus and non-developed gonads on ultrasound align with this diagnosis, as individuals with AIS typically have undescended testes or streak gonads instead of ovaries and a uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Turner's syndrome: Turner's syndrome usually presents in phenotypic females with short stature and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to a chromosomal defect (45,X), which is not consistent with the presence of developed breasts and absent uterus in this case.

 

Option C. Cryptomenorrhea: Cryptomenorrhea refers to the presence of a menstrual obstruction, where the woman has normal ovaries and uterus, which is inconsistent with the ultrasound findings of no uterus.

 

Option D. Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome: Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser Syndrome involves congenital absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina in females who have normal secondary sexual characteristics and normal ovarian function, but they usually have normal pubic and axillary hair development, unlike in AIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • AIS is a condition where an individual who is genetically male (46,XY) is resistant to male hormones (androgens).

questions.text: During a routine review of medicolegal cases, a medical officer at a district hospital is tasked with analyzing a case involving a healthcare professional charged with criminal negligence following a patient's adverse outcome post-surgery. In preparing a report on the case, the medical officer delves into potential legal defences that might be employed by the healthcare professional. The officer is particularly focused on distinguishing which defences are typically not valid in cases of criminal negligence within the medical context. Which of the following is NOT considered a valid legal defence against charges of criminal negligence in the medical field?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contributory negligence

 

  • Contributory negligence, where the plaintiff (patient) is deemed to have contributed to the harm they suffered, is generally not a valid defense in criminal negligence cases within the medical field.
  • Criminal negligence focuses on the healthcare professional's actions and whether they breached the duty of care owed to the patient, rather than on the patient's actions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calculated risk doctrine: This defense acknowledges the inherent risks in medical procedures, where adverse outcomes can occur despite due care and diligence.

 

Option C. Novus actus interveniens: This legal principle refers to an intervening event that breaks the causal link between the defendant's conduct and the ultimate harm, potentially exonerating the defendant from liability.

 

Option D. Medical misadventure: This term describes unforeseen complications arising from medical treatment despite appropriate care, which can be a defense in cases alleging negligence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Contributory negligence – both patient and doctor are at fault. A defense for doctor only in civil negligence, but the onus to proof will lie on Doctor.
  • Two Doctrines are related to contributory negligence –

 

a) Last clear chance Doctrine”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Doctor” still had the last chance to avoid complications. Here the doctor cannot take the defense. 

 

b)  Avoidable consequences rule”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Patient” had the last chance to avoid complications by timely informing the doctor. Here doctor can take the defense

questions.text: A hospital infection control specialist is reviewing data on nosocomial infections related to intravascular catheters. Which species of Pseudomonas is most commonly associated with causing intravascular catheter-related infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common species of Pseudomonas known to cause intravascular catheter-related infections.
  • This organism is notorious for its ability to form biofilms on medical devices, including catheters, which makes it particularly adept at causing persistent hospital-acquired infections.
  • Its prevalence in hospital settings and resistance to many common antibiotics contribute to its prominence in these infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas cepacia: While Burkholderia cepacia (formerly known as Pseudomonas cepacia) can cause healthcare-associated infections, particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis, it is less commonly associated with catheter-related infections compared to P. aeruginosa.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas maltophilia: Stenotrophomonas maltophilia (formerly known as Pseudomonas maltophilia) is another opportunistic pathogen that can be associated with catheter-related infections, but it is not as common as P. aeruginosa.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas mallei: Burkholderia mallei is primarily associated with glanders disease in animals and is not typically involved in catheter-related infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is most troublesome agent of nosocomial infections

choices.text: The Statement A is True, the Statement B is False
The Statement A is False, the Statement B is True
Both the Statements A and B are True
Both the Statements A and B are False

questions.text:
Statement A: The migratory motor complex of the gastrointestinal tract will get repeated every 60 min

 

Statement B: The migratory motor complex will be inactive during fasting periods

 

Which one of the following statement is Accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both the Statements A and B are False

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Migratory Motor Complex (MMC) or Migratory Myoelectric Complex will be active during the interdigestive periods and also during fasting
  • The Gastrointestinal Hormone Motilin (from M0 cells) will be involved in the initiation of migratory motor complex
  • These cycles of motor activity will migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum (in the aboral direction)
  • The entire cycle gets repeated every 90-100 min (not 60 min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Migratory Motor Complex (MMC) typically occurs in cycles of about 90 to 120 minutes, not 60 minutes, and is active during fasting periods to clear the gastrointestinal tract of undigested material.

questions.text:
Match the following local anesthetic agents with the appropriate description: 

 

  1. Local anesthetic used as antiarrythmic
  2. Longest-acting local anesthetic
  3. Shortest-acting local anesthetic
  4. Only naturally occurring local anesthetic with vasoconstrictive properties

 

  1. Chloroprocaine
  2. Lignocaine
  3. Dibucaine
  4. Cocaine
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

  1. b Local anesthetic used as antiarrythmic- Lignocaine
  2. c - Longest-acting local anesthetic: Dibucaine
  3. a - Shortest-acting local anesthetic: Chlorprocaine
  4. d - Only naturally occurring local anesthetic with vasoconstrictive properties: Cocaine

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When selecting a local anesthetic agent, it is crucial to consider the specific characteristics of each drug, such as safety profile, duration of action, and additional effects like vasoconstriction, to best match the clinical scenario.

questions.text: A female patient with a dietary history primarily consisting of maize presents with persistent diarrhea and a rash in the neck region. Which nutrient deficiency is most likely responsible for her clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Niacin

 

  • The patient's symptoms of diarrhea, dermatitis (particularly in sun-exposed areas like the neck, which is known as Casal's necklace), and the dietary history of consuming maize, which lacks niacin and tryptophan, suggest pellagra.
  • Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) and is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.
  • Maize-based diets are commonly associated with niacin deficiency because maize contains niacin in a form that is not bioavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zinc: Zinc deficiency can cause skin lesions, but they usually present as acrodermatitis enteropathica and are not specific to sun-exposed areas.

 

Option C. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency leads to beriberi, which presents with neurological and cardiovascular symptoms, not typically diarrhea or dermatitis in the neck region.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid deficiency is very rare and does not have a specific clinical syndrome associated with it like pellagra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic dermatitis, diarrhea, and potential for neurological symptoms is crucial for the diagnosis and prompt treatment with niacin supplementation.

questions.text: A researcher is examining three different population samples to estimate the average effect of a new drug. The graph presents three normal distributions of sample means with varying sample sizes: 1 (n = 1000), 2 (n = 800), and 3 (n = 600). Based on the information provided, which order correctly represents the margin of error from greatest to least among the three samples?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3>2>1

 

  • The margin of error is inversely related to the sample size; therefore, a larger sample size results in a smaller margin of error.
  • This is due to the central limit theorem, which states that as sample size increases, the sampling distribution of the sample mean will be more closely approximated by a normal distribution with a smaller spread.
  • Given the sample sizes provided, the sample with n=600 (3) would have the largest margin of error, followed by the sample with n=800 (2), and the sample with n=1000 (1) would have the smallest margin of error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Margin of Error: Amount of random sampling error in a survey’s results
  • Margin of error is simply the “radius” (or half the width) of a confidence interval
  • Margin of error = Critical value × Standard error
  • Standard error is inversely related to sample size (SEmean = SD/√Sample size)
  • Margin of error is inversely related to the Sample size

questions.text: In a patient undergoing cancer treatment, which protein is associated with Microtubule Organizing Centers (MTOCs) that becomes a key target due to its crucial role in cell division, making it a promising target for chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubulin

 

  • Tubulin is the protein that polymerizes to form microtubules, which are essential components of the cell's cytoskeleton and play a critical role in cell division, particularly during mitosis.
  • Microtubule Organizing Centers (MTOCs), such as the centrosome, are crucial for the proper assembly and arrangement of microtubules.
  • During cancer treatment, drugs that target tubulin can disrupt microtubule dynamics, inhibiting mitosis and thereby limiting cancer cell proliferation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laminin: Laminin is a protein in the extracellular matrix and is involved in the structure of the basement membrane, not directly involved in cell division.

 

Option B. Keratin: Keratin is a structural protein that forms the intermediate filaments in epithelial cells. It is not associated with MTOCs or directly targeted by chemotherapy drugs.

 

Option D. Ubiquitin: Ubiquitin is a small protein that tags other proteins for degradation. While it plays a role in cell cycle regulation, it is not a direct target in chemotherapy like tubulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tubulin is a primary target of some chemotherapy agents due to its role in microtubule formation and cell division.
  • Inhibiting tubulin can prevent cancer cells from successfully dividing, thereby reducing tumor growth and progression.

questions.text: A male patient with bipolar disorder is controlled on medications, but symptoms of mania appear whenever he tapers down the drugs on his own. Which type of treatment can improve compliance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psychoeducation

 

  • Psychoeducation is highly effective in improving compliance among patients with bipolar disorder.
  • This treatment approach involves educating the patient about the disorder, the importance of maintaining medication adherence, and the consequences of non-compliance such as relapse.
  • By understanding their condition better and the critical role of consistent medication intake, patients are more likely to adhere to their prescribed treatment regimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CBT (Cognitive Behavioural Therapy): It is useful for addressing underlying thought patterns that may contribute to non-compliance or other behaviors, but it may not specifically target the educational aspect about the illness and medication adherence directly as effectively as psychoeducation.

 

Option C. Supportive psychotherapy: It provides emotional support and can help patients deal with the psychological effects of their illness, yet it might not directly increase medication adherence unless combined with direct education about the disorder and treatment.

 

Option D. Insight oriented psychotherapy: It aims to increase a patient’s awareness of underlying psychological processes and conflicts. While beneficial for long-term personal growth and understanding, it may not directly address or improve immediate medication adherence issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psychoeducation helps patients understand the importance of sticking to their prescribed treatment regimens.

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.text: Which ministry is responsible for overseeing the Food Standards and Safety Authority of India (FSSAI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

 

  • The Food Standards and Safety Authority of India (FSSAI) is an agency that falls under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. The FSSAI is responsible for protecting and promoting public health through the regulation and supervision of food safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ministry of Consumer Affairs: While this ministry deals with consumer rights and protection, it does not directly oversee food safety and standards, which are specific to the FSSAI.

 

Option B. Ministry of Agriculture: This ministry is primarily concerned with agricultural policies, production, and supply and does not directly regulate food safety, which is more about the quality of food after production.

 

Option D. Ministry of Rural Development: This ministry focuses on the economic and social development of rural India and is not involved in food safety or public health regulations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS AUTHORITY OF INDIA (FSSAI)
    • Background: Established under Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006
    • Head office: New Delhi
    • Function:
      • Lay down Science-based standards for articles of food and to regulate their manufacture, storage, distribution, sale and import to ensure availability of safe and wholesome food for human consumption.
      • Various Central Acts like Prevention of Food Adulteration Act 1954, Milk and Milk Products Order 1992, etc. to be repealed.
      • Single reference point for all matters relating to food safety and standards
  • Establishment of the Authority: Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Government of India is the Administrative Ministry for the implementation of FSSAI

choices.text: Superficial branch of ulnar nerve

questions.text: A 9-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department with a supracondylar humerus fracture following a fall from a tree. After the injury, the patient is unable to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb on the affected side. Which nerve is most likely injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) AIN (Anterior Interosseous Nerve)

 

  • The inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb typically indicates an injury to the Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN), a motor branch of the median nerve.
  • The AIN specifically innervates the flexor pollicis longus, which controls flexion of the thumb's interphalangeal joint, as well as part of the flexor digitorum profundus, responsible for flexing the distal joints of the fingers.
  • An injury to the AIN in the context of a supracondylar humerus fracture is plausible due to the proximity of this nerve to the elbow joint where such fractures occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve: The median nerve affects a broader range of thumb and finger functions but injury would typically present with additional symptoms, such as sensory deficits in the hand and difficulty with thumb opposition.

 

Option B. Superficial branch of ulnar nerve: The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily affects sensation in the ulnar portion of the hand and some finger movements, but not specifically the flexion of the thumb interphalangeal joint.

 

Option D. PIN (Posterior Interosseous Nerve): The Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN), a branch of the radial nerve, predominantly controls the extension of the wrist and fingers, not flexion of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb typically indicates an injury to the Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN).

questions.text: During an autopsy conducted by a forensic expert at a medical college, skeletal remains are examined. A notable feature observed is the preauricular sulcus on the ilium. The forensic expert evaluates this marker to help determine certain characteristics of the individual. What does the preauricular sulcus primarily help to determine in forensic analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sex

 

  • The preauricular sulcus has been described as a characteristic of the female pelvis. The pelvic portion of the anterior sacroiliac ligament is attached to it.
  • Its prominence results from obstetrical trauma during the course of delivery which allows for differentiation between nulliparous women and males vs females who have given birth

 

 

  • Other methods used for Sex determinations are - 
    • Physical morphology: by External examination 
    • Nuclear sexing or sex chromatin or microscopic test: through examination of Buccal epithelial cells or hair follicle cells to detect the presence of ‘Barr body’.
    • Gonadal biopsy: Detection of ‘internal gonads and sex chromosomes’ (genotype sex), 
    • Gene-based test: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is used to detect SRY gene (sex-determining region of the Y-chromosome) and/or the DYZ1 region of Y chromosome which is diagnostic. 
  • Assay of testosterone levels also helps in differentiating the sex of an individual. For females, they should have levels < 10 nmol/l (lower than the lower limit of normal for male).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Race: The preauricular sulcus does not provide reliable information regarding the race of an individual.

 

Option C. Stature: The presence or characteristics of the preauricular sulcus do not relate to the stature of an individual.

 

Option D. Age: This feature does not vary significantly with age once adulthood is reached and thus does not serve as a reliable marker for aging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preauricular sulcus is used for the determination of sex, one of the feature to differentiate male and female pelvis.

questions.text: A worker in a slaughterhouse develops a malignant pustule on his hand, which later ulcerates. A smear from the ulcer is sent for laboratory analysis. Based on occupational exposure and clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cutaneous anthrax

 

  • Cutaneous anthrax is classically associated with a malignant pustule progressing to a painless ulcer with a black eschar, particularly in individuals who handle potentially infected animal products, like abattoir workers.
  • Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent, can enter through breaks in the skin during the handling of infected animals or animal products, leading to this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is a deep skin infection typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus that presents as a cluster of boils. While painful and purulent, it is not typically associated with the described "malignant pustule" or the occupational risk factors of an abattoir worker.

 

Option C. Ulcerating melanoma: Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can ulcerate, but the presentation would not typically be described as a malignant pustule, nor is it associated with occupational exposure in an abattoir.

 

Option D. Infected rodent ulcer: A rodent ulcer refers to a specific type of skin lesion associated with basal cell carcinoma. An infected rodent ulcer could potentially mimic some features of cutaneous anthrax but lacks the occupational exposure connection and typical malignant pustule presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Malignant pustule is the characteristic feature of cutaneous anthrax

questions.text: A woman with an abdominal mass undergoes surgery and is found to have bilateral ovarian masses with a smooth surface. Microscopic examination shows mucin-secreting cells with signet ring shapes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Krukenberg tumor

 

  • The presence of mucin-secreting cells and signet ring cells in ovarian tumors is characteristic of a Krukenberg tumor.
  • This type of tumor is a metastatic ovarian cancer, typically arising from a primary malignancy in the gastrointestinal tract, such as the stomach or colon.
  • The bilateral nature of the tumors and the specific histological finding of signet ring cells are key indicators for this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor of the ovary and typically presents with different histological features, including large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and centrally located nuclei. It lacks the mucinous and signet ring characteristics.

 

Option C. Mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ovaries: Mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ovaries originates in the ovaries themselves and can contain mucin; however, the presence of bilateral tumors and signet ring cells more strongly suggests a metastatic origin, such as Krukenberg tumor, rather than a primary ovarian origin.

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, or mature cystic teratomas, are benign tumors that can contain a variety of tissue types (including hair, teeth, and fat) but would not typically present with mucin-secreting signet ring cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Krukenberg tumor by its classic presentation of bilateral ovarian masses with mucin-secreting signet ring cells, indicating a metastasis, commonly from a primary site in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text:
Identify the correct agent-disease pairings from the list provided:

 

  1. Lyme disease — Borrelia burgdorferi
  2. Cat-scratch disease — Bartonella henselae
  3. Glanders — Burkholderia mallei
  4. Rat bite fever — Borrelia recurrentis
  5. Trench fever — Bartonella bacilliformis
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Lyme disease — Borrelia burgdorferi: This pairing is correct. Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, which is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks.

 

2. Cat-scratch disease — Bartonella henselae: This is also correct. Cat-scratch disease is an infection that results from a scratch or bite of a cat infected with Bartonella henselae, a bacterium that can also cause other clinical syndromes in humans.

 

3. Glanders — Burkholderia mallei: Correct. Glanders is a disease caused by the bacterium Burkholderia mallei. It primarily affects animals but can be transmitted to humans, causing serious illness.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Rat bite fever — Borrelia recurrentis: This pairing is incorrect. Rat bite fever is caused by either Streptobacillus moniliformis or Spirillum minus, depending on the geographic location, not Borrelia recurrentis, which causes relapsing fever.

 

5. Trench fever — Bartonella bacilliformis: This is incorrect. Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana, not Bartonella bacilliformis, which causes Carrion’s disease or Oroya fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymes-Borelia burgdoreferi
  • Cat scratch— Bartonella henselae
  • Glanders—Burkhulderia mallei
  • Rat bite fever: Streptobacillus moniformis
  • Trench fever: Bartonella Quintana

choices.text: It completely eliminates the chance of developing choriocarcinoma.
Postoperative follow-up is no longer required.
It allows for the simultaneous removal of any enlarged ovaries.
It minimizes the risk of pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered an advantage of performing a hysterectomy in the case of a molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It minimizes the risk of pulmonary embolism.

 

  • In cases of molar pregnancy, performing a hysterectomy can significantly reduce the risk of pulmonary embolism, which occurs when trophoblastic tissue enters the bloodstream and obstructs pulmonary vessels.
  • By removing the uterus, the primary source of abnormal trophoblastic growth is eliminated, reducing the potential for such embolic events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It completely eliminates the chance of developing choriocarcinoma: Removing the uterus does not guarantee that the chance of developing choriocarcinoma becomes nil, as this type of cancer can occur from residual trophoblastic cells that may have metastasized before the hysterectomy.

 

Option B. Postoperative follow-up is no longer required: Follow-up is crucial even after a hysterectomy in cases of molar pregnancy to monitor for residual trophoblastic tissue or metastasis, as indicated by hCG levels.

 

Option C. It allows for the simultaneous removal of any enlarged ovaries: While enlarged ovaries can be evaluated during a hysterectomy, their removal is not typically indicated unless there is a direct complication or suspicion of other pathologies, as the cysts related to molar pregnancies (theca lutein cysts) generally resolve after the mole is removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Monitoring hCG levels post-hysterectomy is critical in ensuring all molar tissue has been addressed and to prevent or identify the development of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, such as choriocarcinoma.

questions.text:
A pediatrician is evaluating the appropriate steps for managing non-immunized individuals who have been in contact with a confirmed case of diphtheria. Which of the following interventions are not recommended in this scenario? 

 

  1. Prophylactic penicillin
  2. Single dose of toxoid
  3. Daily throat examination
  4. Daily throat swab culture
  5. Weekly throat swabs examination
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2,4

 

2. Single dose of toxoid: A single dose of toxoid is not sufficient for immediate protection against diphtheria in non-immunized contacts. A complete vaccination schedule is required to confer immunity, not just a single dose.

 

4. Daily throat swab culture: Performing daily throat swab cultures is not typically recommended due to practicality and resource constraints. It is excessive and not standard practice in the management of diphtheria contacts.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Prophylactic penicillin: This is recommended to eliminate any potential carrier state of the diphtheria bacterium (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) and prevent disease among contacts.

 

3. Daily throat examination: This can be recommended to monitor for symptoms of diphtheria in non-immunized contacts, especially in outbreak situations or high-risk settings.

 

5. Weekly throat swabs examination: Weekly examinations are a practical approach for monitoring contacts over a period, allowing for timely detection of colonization or infection.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Management of diphtheria contacts
    • Immunisation:
      • If primary immunization or booster was received in previous 2 years: No further action
      • If primary immunization or booster was received more than 2 years ago: 1 booster dose
      • If unimmunized contact: Active immunization + 1000-2000 units Antitoxin + Prophylactic penicillin/Erythromycin
    • Examination:
      • Physical examination: Daily for 1 week after exposure
      • Throat swabbing: Weekly for several

questions.text: A 75-year-old male falls in the bathroom and sustains a hip fracture, as seen on a pelvic X-ray. What will likely be the position of the left lower limb?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shortened, externally rotated

 

  • The typical presentation of a hip fracture, particularly a femoral neck fracture or an intertrochanteric fracture, is a limb that appears shortened and externally rotated.
  • This position results from the typical muscular pulls and the way the fracture displaces due to these forces.
  • This is a common finding and is a classic presentation in clinical settings following a hip fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shortened and adducted: Shortened and adducted is less typical for hip fractures, as the limb commonly rotates outward due to muscle imbalances.

 

Option C. Extended, abducted and externally rotated: Extended, abducted and externally rotated is not a typical presentation for a hip fracture and would more likely be seen in different types of hip dislocations or fractures where more complex forces are involved.

 

Option D. Abducted and internally rotated: Abducted and internally rotated is also uncommon for standard hip fractures and does not match the usual pattern of displacement caused by the fracture and muscular forces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The common clinical presentation of a hip fracture, is a shortened and externally rotated lower limb.

questions.text: Which among the following is a cause of posterior mediastinal mass on posterior-anterior (PA) and lateral view of chest radiograph:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bochdalek’s hernia

 

  • Bochdalek’s hernia is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia that typically appears as a posterior mediastinal mass on chest radiographs.
  • It is caused by a posterolateral defect in the diaphragm, which allows abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tortuous innominate artery: A tortuous innominate artery typically presents as a mediastinal widening or as an anterior mediastinal mass, not posteriorly.

 

Option C. Enlarged pulmonary artery: An enlarged pulmonary artery generally appears as an enlargement in the middle mediastinum due to its location and would be more central than posterior.

 

Option D. Thymoma: A thymoma is typically located in the anterior mediastinum, not posteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bochdalek’s hernia is associated with a posterior mediastinal mass on chest radiography, which is important for the differential diagnosis of mediastinal opacities.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hot flushes after cessation of menstruation. Which of the following agents can be used to relieve hot flushes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethinyl estradiol

 

  • Ethinyl estradiol is an estrogen, which is effective in alleviating menopausal symptoms such as hot flushes.
  • These symptoms typically arise due to the decrease in estrogen levels that occurs during menopause.
  • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT), which includes estrogens like ethinyl estradiol, is commonly prescribed to relieve these symptoms by supplementing and stabilizing estrogen levels in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testosterone and C. Fluoxymesterone are androgens and not typically used to treat menopausal symptoms like hot flushes. They are more often associated with hormonal therapies for conditions related to low testosterone levels or certain cancers.

 

Option D. Danazol: Danazol is a synthetic steroid with androgen-like effects and is mainly used for endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease, not for treating menopausal hot flushes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hormone replacement therapy using estrogen, alone or in combination with progesterone, is a common and effective treatment for these symptoms in women experiencing natural or surgically induced menopause.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious with signs of head injury. The initial assessment reveals papilledema. In preparing to intubate the patient for airway protection, the medical team should not choose which anesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketamine

 

  • Ketamine is traditionally contraindicated as it is thought to raise ICP due to its sympathomimetic effects, although recent studies suggest that this may not always be the case, especially when used in conjunction with other ICP-lowering measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propofol: Propofol is often used for its ICP-lowering effects and is generally considered safe for patients with increased ICP.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate is considered safe for patients with increased ICP and does not raise ICP. It has minimal effects on cerebral blood flow and ICP.

 

Option D. Thiopentone sodium: Thiopentone sodium is known to decrease ICP and is often used during the induction of anesthesia in patients with head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the management of an unconscious patient with head injury and raised ICP, ketamine has traditionally been contraindicated due to concerns over increasing ICP, although this stance may be evolving with new evidence.
  • It's essential to choose anesthetic agents that maintain cerebral perfusion and do not exacerbate intracranial hypertension.

choices.text: The causative organism shows corkscrew motility
Extragenital syphilitic chancre can occur on the fingers
Dory flop sign can be seen in uncircumcised males

questions.text: A commercial sex worker has come forward with a hard, painless sore on the vulva and accompanying painless swelling in the inguinal lymph nodes. What statement is FALSE regarding the likely condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The incubation period is 2-5 days

 

  • The patient's presentation is suggestive of primary syphilis, which is typically characterized by a painless ulcer (chancre) and non-tender lymphadenopathy.
  • The causative organism, Treponema pallidum, exhibits corkscrew motility. Extragenital chancres, including on the fingers, are possible with syphilis. The dory flop sign refers to the foreskin being retracted behind the corona of the glans penis and stuck there, which can sometimes be seen in the context of genital lesions, including syphilis.
  • However, the statement about the incubation period being 2-5 days is false. The incubation period for primary syphilis is usually around three weeks but can range from 10 to 90 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The causative organism shows corkscrew motility: Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, is known for its corkscrew motility under dark-field microscopy.

 

Option C. Extragenital syphilitic chancre can occur on the fingers: Syphilis can indeed present with extragenital chancres, such as on the fingers, if those areas come into contact with the spirochete.

 

Option D. Dory flop sign can be seen in uncircumcised males: While not commonly referred to in the context of syphilis, dory flop sign might be mentioned as a non-specific sign related to genital lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of a painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy suggests primary syphilis, where the causative organism shows corkscrew motility and the incubation period is longer than 2-5 days, typically around three weeks.
  • Understanding the signs, symptoms, and characteristics of syphilis is important for proper diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text:
Based on the current understanding of HPV-associated conditions, which of the following can result from an HPV infection?

 

  1. Cervical cancer
  2. Anal cancer
  3. Oropharyngeal cancer
  4. Laryngeal papillomatosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • HPV infection is known to be associated with several types of cancers and other health conditions due to its ability to cause persistent infection and cellular changes in various tissues:

 

1. Cervical cancer: HPV is the primary cause of cervical cancer, with types 16 and 18 responsible for the majority of cases.

 

2. Anal cancer: HPV infection is also linked to a significant proportion of anal cancers, particularly in individuals with HPV types 16 and 18.

 

3. Oropharyngeal cancer: Certain HPV types, especially HPV 16, have been increasingly associated with oropharyngeal cancers, affecting areas such as the base of the tongue and tonsils.

 

4. Laryngeal papillomatosis: This condition, characterized by the growth of benign tumors in the airways, is caused by HPV, typically types 6 and 11, which are less often associated with cancers but linked to other benign lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

  • All options listed are correct manifestations of HPV infection, reinforcing the varied impact of this virus on human health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV-related Cancers
    • Cervical cancer (HPV 16,18)
    • Oropharyngeal cancers (HPV 16)
    • Genital warts (HPV 6,11)
    • Laryngeal papillomatosis (HPV 6,11)
    • Anal cancer
    • Penile cancer
    • Vaginal cancer
    • Vulvar cancer

choices.text: Leakage of fluid into the peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis
Fluid from wetting the surgeon
Fluids running out during the procedure
Electrolyte imbalance in the patient

questions.text: During a hysteroscopy, a surgeon is performing a diagnostic evaluation on a 35-year-old woman for abnormal uterine bleeding. The procedure involves the introduction of fluid into the uterine cavity to expand it and improve visibility. The surgeon is mindful of the volume and type of fluid used, as well as the patient's fluid balance. Understanding the significance of fluid management during this procedure, which of the following is the most critical reason for careful fluid monitoring during hysteroscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Electrolyte imbalance in the patient

 

  • The most critical reason for careful fluid management during hysteroscopy is to prevent electrolyte imbalance in the patient.
  • During hysteroscopy, fluid is used to distend the uterine cavity, which can sometimes be absorbed into the patient's bloodstream.
  • This can lead to a condition known as fluid overload or, depending on the type of fluid used, specific imbalances like hyponatremia if hypotonic solutions are absorbed in significant quantities.
  • Managing the volume and type of fluid used is crucial to prevent these potentially serious complications.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Leakage of fluid into the peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis: While fluid can inadvertently enter the peritoneal cavity during procedures, it typically does not lead to peritonitis unless the fluid is contaminated, which is a rare occurrence with proper sterile techniques.

 

Option B. Fluid from wetting the surgeon: While maintaining a dry surgical field is important for the comfort of the surgical team and the integrity of the procedure, it is not the most critical reason for fluid management during hysteroscopy.

 

Option C. Fluids running out during the procedure: Preventing fluid loss is important for maintaining visibility and distension of the uterine cavity during hysteroscopy, but it is not as critical as preventing electrolyte imbalances in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary objective of careful fluid management during hysteroscopy is to prevent electrolyte imbalances in the patient, such as hyponatremia, which can occur due to the absorption of irrigation fluids into the bloodstream.
  • Understanding the implications of fluid absorption and the potential for fluid overload is essential for the safe conduct of hysteroscopic procedures.

questions.text: During the process of evaluating protein concentration in a laboratory setting, which of the following amino acids is primarily responsible for the absorption of ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 280 nm, allowing for the spectrophotometric analysis of protein solutions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tryptophan

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid that strongly absorbs ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 280 nm due to its indole ring structure.
  • This property is exploited in methods such as spectrophotometry to measure protein concentration in laboratory assays.
  • Phenylalanine and tyrosine, two other aromatic amino acids, also absorb UV light, but tryptophan has the strongest absorption and is typically the most significant contributor to a protein's UV absorbance profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leucine: Leucine does not absorb UV light at 280 nm significantly because it lacks an aromatic ring structure.

 

Option B. Proline: Proline also does not significantly absorb UV light at 280 nm as it is not an aromatic amino acid.

 

Option C. Arginine: Arginine does not contribute to UV absorption at 280 nm significantly due to the lack of an aromatic ring structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The properties of aromatic amino acids, specifically tryptophan, allows them to absorb ultraviolet light.
  • This absorption is utilized in laboratory techniques to analyze and quantify protein concentrations.

choices.text: Group A has higher systolic blood pressure readings with greater variability on the lower end.
Group A has a symmetrical distribution of systolic blood pressure readings.
Group B has a positively skewed distribution of systolic blood pressure readings.
Group B has lower systolic blood pressure readings with greater variability on the lower end.

questions.text: A medical researcher is comparing the distribution of systolic blood pressure readings between two different groups of patients. The researcher creates a Box and Whisker plot for each group. If Group A's plot shows a median closer to the third quartile with longer whiskers on the lower end, while Group B's plot has a median closer to the first quartile and longer upper whiskers, what can be inferred about the blood pressure readings between the two groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Group B has a positively skewed distribution of systolic blood pressure readings.

 

  • Group B's Box and Whisker plot, with a median closer to the first quartile and longer whiskers on the upper end, indicates that there is a tail in the distribution toward the higher values, suggesting a positively skewed distribution.
  • This means that there is a larger spread of blood pressure readings on the higher end for Group B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Group A has higher systolic blood pressure readings with greater variability on the lower end: The location of the median near the third quartile for Group A suggests that the group might have higher readings, but the longer lower whiskers indicate more variability on the lower end, not necessarily higher values overall.

 

Option B. Group A has a symmetrical distribution of systolic blood pressure readings: The description of the median's position suggests asymmetry in the distribution.

 

Option D. Group B has lower systolic blood pressure readings with greater variability on the lower end: The description provided indicates that Group B has more variability on the higher end, not the lower end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Box and Whisker Plot’
    • Sides of boxes represent Quartiles 1st and 3rd; Line inside the Box is 2nd Quartile (Median)
    • Whiskers on the side represent Minimum and Maximum value
  • If Median line (Q2) in exact centre of box, Its bilaterally symmetrical Normal distribution
    • But if Median line is towards a side of the box, Its skewed distribution

questions.text: A cardiologist is reviewing the electrocardiogram of a patient who is experiencing irregular heartbeats. They focus on the repolarization phase of the action potential. Which ionic movement is responsible for phase 3 of the cardiac action potential?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Potassium efflux 

 

  • During phase 3, increased permeability to potassium allows K+ to flow out of the cell, returning the membrane potential towards its resting level, a process essential for repolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium influx: Incorrect. Sodium influx occurs during phase 0 of the action potential and is responsible for the rapid depolarization of the cardiac cell membrane.

 

Option C. Calcium influx: Incorrect. Calcium influx characterizes phase 2, the plateau phase, of the cardiac action potential, which sustains the depolarization and allows for the contraction of the heart muscle.

 

Option D. Sodium efflux: Incorrect. Sodium efflux is not a significant feature of phase 3; instead, the Na+/K+ ATPase helps restore the resting potential, but this occurs after repolarization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential, phase 3, is dominated by the efflux of potassium ions, which leads to the restoration of the resting membrane potential of cardiac muscle cells.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the psychiatry outpatient department complaining that he feels as if he has changed from the inside. He describes feeling strange and different from his normal self, expressing significant tension and anxiety but is unable to specify exactly what has changed. This phenomenon is best described as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Depersonalization

 

  • Depersonalization refers to a dissociative symptom in which individuals feel detached from themselves or their surroundings, often feeling as if they are an external observer of their own behavior.
  • It can include a sense of experiencing one's life as unreal or observing oneself from outside.
  • The description given by the boy aligns well with depersonalization, where he feels "strange" and "different" as if he has changed from within, which encapsulates the essence of feeling detached or estranged from one’s self.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusional mood: Delusional mood is a state where an individual feel that something ominous is happening but cannot specifically identify what it is. It generally precedes the development of a clear-cut delusion, but does not directly describe a sense of self-alteration or detachment as in this case.

 

Option C. Autochthonous delusion: Autochthonous delusion refers to a delusion that seems to appear out of nowhere, fully formed. This does not fit the boy's complaint of feeling changed or different without a specific, identifiable belief.

 

Option D. Overvalued idea: Overvalued idea is an exaggerated belief that is persistently held despite evidence to the contrary but is not bizarre or impossible. It typically does not involve feelings of detachment or estrangement from oneself, but rather a disproportionate preoccupation with a particular idea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Depersonalization involves a disruption in how one perceives or experiences their sense of self and can be distressing, particularly in the absence of other psychotic symptoms such as clear delusions or hallucinations.

questions.text: During a hysterosalpingography, a patient's fallopian tubes appear beaded with clubbing of the fimbrial end and the ampulla. What is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

  • The beaded appearance of the fallopian tubes with clubbing at the fimbrial ends and ampulla in hysterosalpingography is most characteristic of tubal damage caused by tuberculosis.
  • Tuberculosis of the genital tract, particularly affecting the fallopian tubes, can lead to significant scarring and deformity, manifesting as beading and clubbing in imaging studies.
  • This specific pattern is suggestive of chronic infection and fibrosis typically seen in tubercular infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candidiasis: Candidiasis generally affects the vaginal area, cervix, and vulva more commonly than the fallopian tubes and typically does not cause the type of tubal changes seen in hysterosalpingography.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia infection can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) which may lead to scarring of the fallopian tubes; however, the beading and clubbing appearance is more specifically associated with tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Gonococcus: Gonococcus, another common cause of PID, can result in scarring and potential damage to the fallopian tubes, but the specific appearance of beading and clubbing is less typical than with tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic appearance of beaded fallopian tubes with clubbing of the fimbrial ends and ampulla, as observed during hysterosalpingography, is highly indicative of tubal tuberculosis.

questions.text: A cardiologist is assessing a patient's functional capacity related to heart disease using the New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Classification. The patient reports an inability to perform any physical activity without discomfort. Which NYHA class does this symptom correspond to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) New York Heart Association 4

 

  • NYHA Class 4 is characterized by a patient's inability to carry out any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of heart failure are present even at rest, significantly increasing discomfort upon any physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NYHA 1: Patients with NYHA Class 1 have no limitations of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea (shortness of breath).

 

Option B. NYHA 2: Patients classified under NYHA Class 2 have slight, mild limitations of physical activity. They are comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea.

 

Option C. NYHA 3: NYHA Class 3 involves marked limitation of physical activity. Although patients are comfortable at rest, less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • New York Heart Association (NYHA) Classification
  • Importance: Scale used for quantification of degree of functional limitation imposed by Congestive health failure (CHF)

 

 

(*Class IIIa No dyspnoea at rest; Class IIIb Dyspnoea at rest)

choices.text: To reapply the patch with another adhesive
To apply a new patch
To apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week
To remove the patch and use a condom until her next menstrual period

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, who has been using the transdermal contraceptive patch as her primary method of contraception, presents to the outpatient department. She reports that her contraceptive patch was partially detached for more than 24 hours. Considering the potential compromise in the patch's effectiveness due to this incident, what would be the most appropriate advice for her to ensure continuous contraceptive protection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week

 

  • The correct advice would be to apply a new patch immediately and use a backup method of contraception, such as a condom, for the next 7 days.
  • When a transdermal contraceptive patch is detached for more than 24 hours, its effectiveness can be compromised, and there is a risk of reduced contraceptive protection.
  • Applying a new patch restores contraceptive coverage, but the backup method is necessary to ensure protection while the hormone levels from the new patch reach effective concentrations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To reapply the patch with another adhesive: This is not recommended because the patch's ability to deliver hormones at the correct rate may be compromised if it has been detached, especially for an extended period.

 

Option B. To apply a new patch: While applying a new patch is part of the correct action, this option alone does not address the need for a backup contraceptive method during the period when the hormone levels may not yet be fully effective.

 

Option D. To remove the patch and use a condom until her next menstrual period: This option might provide immediate contraceptive protection through the use of condoms, but it does not take into account the immediate re-establishment of hormonal contraception, which the woman may prefer for ongoing contraceptive coverage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In instances where the patch has been detached for an extended period, applying a new patch and using a backup contraceptive method, such as condoms, for the next 7 days is crucial to ensure ongoing contraceptive efficacy.
  • This approach addresses both the immediate need for contraception and the potential gap in hormonal coverage due to the detachment.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department with a hemorrhagic bullous lesion at the site of a dog bite. Which organism is most likely responsible for this type of severe skin infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a common pathogen associated with skin and soft tissue infections, which can range from mild to severe.
  • In cases of dog bites, although less typical than Capnocytophaga canimorsus, Staphylococcus aureus can indeed cause severe infections, especially if the bite becomes secondarily infected.
  • This bacterium is capable of producing toxins that lead to the rapid progression of infection symptoms, including the development of hemorrhagic bullous lesions.
  • These lesions are characterized by fluid-filled blisters that may appear bloody and are often a sign of a deeper, more severe infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas: Known for causing infections in wounds, especially in hospital settings, but not the most common cause of infection directly following a dog bite.

 

Option C. Capnocytophaga: While it is a common bacterium in the mouths of dogs and can cause severe infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, it typically presents with sepsis and less frequently with hemorrhagic bullous lesions.

 

Option D. Vibrio vulnificus: Associated with exposure to seawater or contaminated seafood and not related to dog bites.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Jaw thrust maneuver
Triple airway maneuver

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sellick’s maneuver

 

  • The maneuver shown in the image is Sellick's maneuver.
  • Sellick's maneuver: Also known as cricoid pressure, this maneuver is applied to occlude the esophagus by compressing it against the cervical vertebrae.
  • It is intended to prevent gastric contents from entering the upper airway and lungs during induction of anesthesia and intubation, thereby reducing the risk of aspiration.
  • The image shows the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, which is consistent with Sellick's maneuver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heimlich maneuver: This is an emergency technique used in cases of airway obstruction due to a foreign object. It involves abdominal thrusts to expel the object from the airway. This is not what is depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Jaw thrust maneuver: This maneuver involves displacing the jaw forward without tilting the head to open the airway in a patient who may have a cervical spine injury. It is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Triple airway maneuver: This technique involves opening the airway by tilting the head back, lifting the chin, and possibly opening the mouth. This is not what is shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sellick's maneuver, also known as cricoid pressure, is applied to the cricoid cartilage to prevent passive regurgitation of gastric contents during induction of anesthesia and is especially important in patients at risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A pediatric patient comes in with an infectious skin lesion on the leg. Culture of the lesion grows hemolytic colonies consisting of Gram-positive cocci in chains. Which test would be most appropriate to confirm the identity of the organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacitracin sensitivity

 

  • Gram-positive cocci in chains producing hemolytic colonies are characteristic of Group A Streptococcus (GAS), also known as Streptococcus pyogenes, which is a common cause of skin infections in children.
  • The bacitracin sensitivity test is used to differentiate S. pyogenes (which is typically bacitracin sensitive) from other beta-hemolytic streptococci.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bile solubility: This test is used to distinguish Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is bile soluble, from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity: The optochin sensitivity test is also used to identify S. pneumoniae, which is optochin sensitive, as opposed to other viridans group streptococci.

 

Option D. Catalase positive: Streptococci are catalase-negative, which helps to differentiate them from catalase-positive organisms such as Staphylococcus spp. Since the organism in question is a Streptococcus (as indicated by the morphology of being in chains), it would be catalase negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hemolytic colony with gram-positive cocci in chain is suggestive of β hemolytic Streptococcus.
  • Bacitracin sensitivity is used to differentiate between β hemolytic Streptococci Group A- Bacitracin sensitive and Group b: Bacitracin resistant
  • Bile solubility and Optochin sensitivity are used to differentiate Pneumococcus and S. Viridans
  • Catalase test is used to differentiate Streptococcus and Staphylococcus.

questions.text: During an autopsy, a forensic expert investigates the cause of death of an infant found under suspicious circumstances. To help determine if the infant was alive at the time of death, the expert decides to conduct Breslau's second life test. Which organ is primarily examined in this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stomach

 

  • Breslau's second life test, also known as the stomach bowel test, involves examining the stomach and intestines to determine if respiration occurred before death.
  • In this test, the stomach and intestines are removed, tied at both ends, and submerged in water.
  • An incision is made between the ties, and the presence of air bubbles indicates that respiration has occurred, suggesting that the infant was alive before death.
  • Additionally, the presence of substances such as milk in the stomach can provide positive evidence of live birth, helping forensic experts determine life status at the time of death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver is not relevant to Breslau’s second life test, as it does not provide information about respiratory activity or the presence of air in the digestive tract.

 

Option C. Ear: The ears are not examined in Breslau’s second life test as they do not contribute to determining respiratory activity in the context of this test.

 

Option D. Lungs: While lung examinations are critical in many forensic tests to determine if an individual was breathing at the time of death, they are not the focus of Breslau’s second life test, which specifically utilizes the stomach and intestines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Breslau's second life test involves examining the stomach and intestines.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man undergoing a routine checkup is found to have serum alkaline phosphatase levels three times the upper limit of normal. Serum calcium, phosphorous concentrations, and liver function tests are normal. He is asymptomatic. What is the most probable cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's disease of bone

 

  • Paget's disease of bone is a likely cause of an isolated increase in serum alkaline phosphatase, particularly in an asymptomatic elderly individual.
  • Paget's disease involves the excessive breakdown and formation of bone, leading to enlarged and misshapen bones.
  • This condition commonly results in an elevated alkaline phosphatase level due to increased bone turnover, while calcium, phosphorous, and liver function tests remain within normal ranges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma could also involve elevated alkaline phosphatase if there is extensive bone involvement, but it typically presents with symptoms such as bone pain, anemia, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism: Primary hyperparathyroidism typically presents with hypercalcemia, which leads to symptoms of stones (kidney stones), bones (bone pain), moans (abdominal discomfort), and groans (psychiatric overtones), none of which are noted in this patient.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia involves softening of the bones due to problems with bone formation or bone building, which might increase alkaline phosphatase. However, it would likely also present with abnormalities in calcium or phosphorous levels, or present symptoms related to bone weakness or pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An isolated increase in alkaline phosphatase in an asymptomatic elderly patient, particularly with normal calcium, phosphorous, and liver function tests, is suggestive of Paget's disease of bone.

questions.text: In a case where dye-filled into the urinary bladder does not stain a pad placed in the vagina, but the pad is soaked with clear urine, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ureterovaginal fistula

 

  • A ureterovaginal fistula is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario. In this condition, there is an abnormal connection between one of the ureters and the vagina, which allows urine to bypass the bladder entirely and flow directly from the ureters into the vagina.
  • This explains why the dye that was filled into the bladder does not stain the pad (since the bladder isn't the source of the leakage), yet the pad is soaked with clear urine (from the ureters).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF): Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) would typically result in the dye-stained urine leaking into the vagina because it involves a connection between the bladder and the vagina.

 

Option C. Urinary stress incontinence: Urinary stress incontinence typically results from weakened pelvic floor muscles or a weakened urethral sphincter, leading to urine leakage during physical activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or sneezing, but it does not involve uncontaminated urine leaking continuously.

 

Option D. Urethrovaginal fistula: Urethrovaginal fistula would also likely result in the dye reaching the pad since it involves a connection between the urethra and the vagina, and thus urine (and dye) would pass from the bladder through the fistula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ureterovaginal fistula is crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning, particularly in cases where urine leaks without associated dye from the bladder, pointing directly to an abnormal connection involving the ureters rather than the bladder or urethra.
  • This insight guides further diagnostic imaging and appropriate surgical intervention to correct the fistula.

choices.text: Ingestion of egg contaminated in water

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with gastrointestinal discomfort, diarrhea, and mild abdominal pain. He reports a history of camping. A stool sample is obtained, and on microscopic examination, an egg similar to the one pictured is observed. Which is the most likely mode of transmission and infective form of the parasite corresponding to this egg?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ingestion of egg contaminated in water

 

  • This is an egg from a species of Trematodes (flukes) or Cestodes (tapeworms), many of which are transmitted by ingestion of contaminated water or food.
  • The ingestion of eggs contaminated in water is a common mode of transmission for various waterborne helminth infections.
  • When humans ingest these eggs, they can hatch in the gastrointestinal tract, releasing larvae that mature into adult worms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ingestion of uncooked/raw beef: This is typically associated with tapeworm infections such as Taenia saginata, where the infective form is the cysticercus larva, not the egg.

 

Option C. Penetration by filariform larva: This is the mode of transmission for hookworms, where the infective filariform larvae penetrate the skin, not through egg ingestion.

 

Option D. Penetration by rhabditiform larva: This is not a typical infective form for human parasitic infections; rhabditiform larvae are generally a non-infective stage found in the environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Egg of Trichuris trichiura - It spreads by ingestion of egg contaminated in water.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray of spine shows calcification of IV disc. On adding benedicts reagent to urine, it gives greenish brown precipitate and blue-black supernatant fluid. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

 

  • The clinical presentation described is classic for alkaptonuria, a rare metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase.
  • This leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which can be oxidized to benzoquinone acetate, a pigment-forming compound that deposits in connective tissues (ochronosis), causing the characteristic palmoplantar pigmentation.
  • Calcification of the intervertebral discs and other cartilage is also common.
  • The greenish-brown precipitate and blue-black supernatant fluid upon adding Benedict's reagent to urine are due to the presence of homogentisic acid, which is excreted in the urine and darkens upon exposure to air and alkaline conditions (alkapton).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria (PKU): It is characterized by mental retardation, seizures, and fair skin. The urine in PKU does not produce the described color change upon the addition of Benedict's reagent but might have a mousy odor.

 

Option C. Tyrosinemia type 2: It can lead to painful palmoplantar lesions but is associated with corneal ulcers and mental retardation. It does not result in urine turning dark upon standing or with alkali addition.

 

Option D. Argininosuccinic aciduria: It usually presents with hyperammonemia and its sequelae but does not cause darkening of urine or ochronosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical features of alkaptonuria, include palmoplantar pigmentation, calcification of intervertebral discs, and a characteristic color change of urine on standing or upon alkali addition.
  • This metabolic disorder is diagnosed by the presence of homogentisic acid in the urine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, para 6, experiences excessive bleeding post-vaginal delivery despite interventions including manual exploration, bimanual massage, intravenous oxytocin, and 0.2 mg methergine IV. What is the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Injection of PGF 2α (Prostaglandin F2 alpha)

 

  • Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF 2α) is the next appropriate step for managing this patient's postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) after initial measures have failed.
  • PGF 2α is effective in inducing potent uterine contractions, which can help to control bleeding by compressing bleeding vessels within the uterine wall.
  • This medication is often used when oxytocin and methergine do not successfully control the bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Packing the uterus: Packing the uterus can be considered if pharmacologic measures fail and before more invasive procedures are attempted. It can provide tamponade to help control bleeding but is less ideal as it may delay definitive treatment.

 

Option B. Immediate hysterectomy: Immediate hysterectomy is a definitive treatment for uncontrolled PPH but is considered a last resort due to its permanent nature and the significant impact on the patient’s future fertility and hormonal status.

 

Option C. Bilateral internal iliac ligation: Bilateral internal iliac artery ligation is another surgical intervention that reduces pelvic blood flow and can help control bleeding. However, it is less commonly performed due to the need for surgical expertise, the risk of complications, and the availability of less invasive options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PGF 2α serves as an effective next step following the standard first-line treatments, offering a balance between efficacy and invasiveness, with an immediate impact on uterine tone.

choices.text: None of them is used for evaluation

questions.text: When evaluating the prevalence of blindness using schools as the survey setting compared to broader population surveys, what is the likely impact on the estimation of blindness prevalence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Underestimation

 

  • Using schools as a survey setting for estimating the prevalence of blindness is likely to result in an underestimation of the true prevalence.
  • This is because the school-going population is generally younger and less likely to be affected by age-related causes of blindness, such as cataracts, glaucoma, and macular degeneration, which are common in older adults.
  • Additionally, children with severe disabilities, including blindness, may be underrepresented in typical school settings due to accessibility and inclusion issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Overestimation: This would not be typical unless the schools were specifically for visually impaired students, which is not implied in the general context of using schools for surveys.

 

Option C. Remains the same: This is unlikely as the demographic profile of school-aged children does not represent the entire population, particularly the older age groups most affected by blindness.

 

Option D. None of them is used for evaluation: This is incorrect as both methods can be used for evaluation, but they serve different purposes and contexts, potentially yielding different results in prevalence estimation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Blindness situation in India:
    • Estimated prevalence of Blindness in India (Total): 11.2 per 1000 population
    • Estimated prevalence of Blindness in India (0-14 years): 0.1 per 1000 population
    • Estimated prevalence of Blindness in India (15-49 years): 0.6 per 1000 population
    • Estimated prevalence of Blindness in India (50+ years): 77.3 per 1000 population
  • So if Schools are used where only refractive errors generally constitute blindness (that too very few are actually blind i.e. <3/60) AS COMPARED TO POPULATION (where age-related cataract constitute as major cause of blindness), it would lead to underestimation of prevalence of blindness in the country

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoing long-term steroid therapy complains of sudden severe pain in the right hip. What is the preferred imaging study to evaluate this complaint?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MRI

 

  • Long-term steroid use is a risk factor for osteonecrosis (also known as avascular necrosis), especially in the hip joint, which can present as sudden onset of severe pain.
  • MRI is the imaging modality of choice for early detection of osteonecrosis as it can identify bone marrow edema and early changes in bone and cartilage before they are evident on a plain X-ray or CT scan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan: A CT scan is useful for visualizing complex bone fractures and planning surgical interventions but is less sensitive than MRI for early changes of osteonecrosis.

 

Option B. Bone scan: A bone scan can detect areas of increased bone turnover and may be useful for a variety of bone pathologies but is less specific than MRI for early osteonecrosis.

 

Option D. Plain X-ray: Plain X-ray is usually the first imaging modality used for bone problems, but it may not show early osteonecrosis until the disease has progressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MRI is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating suspected osteonecrosis in patients on long-term steroid therapy, due to its sensitivity in detecting early changes in the bone and marrow.
  • It's crucial for early diagnosis and potential management to prevent further joint damage.

questions.text: Avoiding awareness of the pain of reality by negating sensory data is seen in which of the following defense mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Denial

 

  • Denial is a defense mechanism in which an individual refuse to accept the reality of a painful or distressing situation, effectively denying the existence of the sensory data that would lead to accepting that reality.
  • By denying reality, the person protects themselves from experiencing the pain or discomfort associated with that reality.
  • Denial involves a subconscious refusal to see the facts or to acknowledge what is evident to others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distortion: Distortion involves changing the reality of a situation in one's mind so that it is less threatening, which is different from outright denial of the reality.

 

Option C. Displacement: Displacement is a defense mechanism where negative feelings, frustrations, or impulses are redirected from the original source to a less threatening target.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Dissociation is a more complex mechanism where a person mentally separates themselves from a part of their life or consciousness that is too difficult to handle, leading to a disconnection from reality, but not through the denial of sensory data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Denial specifically allows individuals to navigate painful realities by blocking acknowledgment of that reality, which can temporarily shield them from acute distress but may also prevent addressing and resolving underlying issues.

questions.text:
