A public health professional is designing a program aimed at the primary prevention of hypertension. Which of the following interventions are considered primary preventive measures to reduce the risk of developing hypertension?

 

  1. Weight reduction
  2. Dietary salt reduction
  3. Exercise promotion
  4. Early diagnosis
  5. Antihypertensive drugs
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1,2,3: Weight reduction, Dietary salt reduction, Exercise promotion

 

1. Weight reduction: Managing weight is crucial in preventing hypertension. Excess body weight is a significant risk factor for developing high blood pressure, and weight loss has been shown to help decrease blood pressure levels.

 

2. Dietary salt reduction: High salt intake is linked with increased blood pressure. Reducing salt in the diet can prevent the onset of hypertension in individuals at risk.

 

3. Exercise promotion: Regular physical activity helps maintain a healthy blood pressure level and reduces the risk of hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Early diagnosis: This is considered a secondary prevention strategy. Early diagnosis aims to mitigate the disease's progression and manage existing hypertension, rather than preventing its onset.

 

5. Antihypertensive drugs: Using medications to manage blood pressure is part of treatment rather than primary prevention. This approach is applicable once hypertension is diagnosed, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Early diagnosis, Antihypertensive drugs are Secondary level of prevention for Hypertension

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of itching in vagina, discharge from vagina and dyspareunia. Best treatment option would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal estrogen

 

  • The presentation of vaginal itching, discharge, and dyspareunia in a 60-year-old woman is suggestive of atrophic vaginitis, a condition common in postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels leading to thinning and inflammation of the vaginal walls.
  • Vaginal estrogen therapy is the most effective treatment for atrophic vaginitis, as it helps to restore the vaginal mucosa's thickness, elasticity, and secretions, alleviating the symptoms of itching, discharge, and dyspareunia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal metronidazole: This is used to treat bacterial vaginosis, which typically presents with a fishy-smelling vaginal discharge and may or may not include itching or irritation. The patient's symptoms and age make atrophic vaginitis more likely than bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option B. Vaginal clindamycin: Similar to metronidazole, vaginal clindamycin is indicated for bacterial vaginosis, not for symptoms primarily due to atrophic changes in the vaginal mucosa.

 

Option C. Vaginal clotrimazole: Clotrimazole is an antifungal medication used to treat yeast infections, characterized by thick, white vaginal discharge and significant itching. While itching is a common symptom, the overall presentation and the patient's age suggest that atrophic vaginitis is more likely the cause of her symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaginal estrogen is the treatment of choice for relieving symptoms associated with atrophic changes in the vagina, such as itching, discharge, and dyspareunia.

questions.text:
A healthcare facility manager is training new staff on infection control practices and the use of disinfectants. The manager emphasizes the importance of choosing appropriate agents for sterilization and the elimination of bacterial spores. Which of the listed agents are sporicidal?

 

  1. Glutaraldehyde
  2. Ethylene oxide
  3. Formaldehyde
  4. Benzalkonium chloride
  5. Chlorine
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

Glutaraldehyde, ethylene oxide, and formaldehyde are all agents known for their sporicidal properties. They have the ability to destroy all forms of microbial life, including highly resistant spores.

 

  • Glutaraldehyde is used as a high-level disinfectant and sterilant in medical settings, particularly for equipment that cannot be heat sterilized.
  • Ethylene oxide is a gaseous sterilant used for materials sensitive to heat and moisture.
  • Formaldehyde is used in both its liquid and gas forms as a disinfectant and sterilant.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Benzalkonium chloride: This is a quaternary ammonium compound used mainly as a disinfectant. It has good bactericidal properties against vegetative bacteria but is not considered sporicidal.

 

5. Chlorine: While chlorine compounds, such as sodium hypochlorite, have broad antimicrobial activity and can be sporicidal at high concentrations, chlorine as a gas is primarily used for water treatment and not typically for sterilization of medical equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporicidal agents include:

 

  • EFGH: Ethylene oxide, Formaldehyde, Glutaraldehyde, Hydrogen peroxide.
  • 3P: Peracetic acid, O-Phthalic acid and Plasma sterilization.
  • Autoclave, hot air oven and incineration.

choices.text: Nail pitting seen is of deep irregular & coarse type
Joint involvement is seen in 5-30% of patients

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding Psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Deficient Th1 & Th17 helper cells

 

  • Psoriasis is an immune-mediated disease characterized by an increase, not a deficiency, in Th1 and Th17 helper cell activities.
  • These T-cell subtypes are involved in the overactive immune response that leads to the inflammation and rapid turnover of skin cells observed in psoriasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nail pitting seen is of deep irregular & coarse type: Nail pitting in psoriasis is typically deep, irregular, and coarse.

 

Option B. Genetic predisposition HLA-C 06:02: There is a known genetic predisposition in psoriasis with the HLA-C 06:02 allele being one of the genetic markers associated with the condition.

 

Option C. Joint involvement is seen in 5-30% of patients: Joint involvement, known as psoriatic arthritis, occurs in a subset of patients with psoriasis, ranging from 5-30%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriasis involves an overactive immune response mediated by T-cell subtypes, particularly Th1 and Th17, which leads to increased inflammation and skin cell turnover.
